newsitem.title: TAIWAN: What price Taiwan's success at Europe parliament?.
newsitem.headline: What price Taiwan's success at Europe parliament?.

text.p: Taiwan on Friday hailed as a success its foreign minister's address to the European Parliament, but political analysts were deeply sceptical about its benefits in view of arch-rival China's vitriolic reaction.

Taiwan media trumpeted Foreign Minister John Chang's visit to the European legislature in Brussels on Thursday, calling it a breakthrough in Taiwan's drive to shake free of China's steadily tightening diplomatic embargo.
Chang slipped out of Taiwan on Monday for Belgium in the latest of a series of secretive overseas visits to promote Taiwan's relations with Europe.
Taipei would not confirm Chang's plan to address a committee of the European Parliament until just hours before he spoke, a gambit aiming to give Beijing little time to interfere.
State media said Chang would visit Luxembourg on Friday and unconfirmed reports said he would travel next to West Africa.

The foreign ministry hailed the European Parliament for "defying the barbarism of the Chinese communists" by offering Chang a forum despite Beijing's opposition and by condemning the intimidating war games that China mounted near Taiwan in the months before the island's March 1996 presidential election.
"At a time of increased hardship in our international situation, it (the speech) was highly significant," the foreign ministry said in a statement.
China has considered Taiwan a rebel province since a civil war split them in 1949, leaving the mainland in communist hands and the island of 21 million with the defeated Nationalists.
Beijing has sought to isolate Taiwan in a quest to bring it under mainland rule, squeezing China's diplomatic partners to give Taiwan and its travelling officials no quarter.

Facing such pressure, Taiwan's diplomatic alliances have shrunk to a handful. With the recent loss of the Bahamas, only 30 states recognise Taiwan's exiled Republic of China. The number will fall to 29 when South Africa switches this year.

In a strongly worded protest, Beijing on Thursday condemned the European Parliament for inviting Chang to speak, calling this a serious encroachment on China's sovereignty and gross interference in China's internal affairs.
Analysts were unsure whether Chang's speech would help Taiwan or merely exacerbate Taiwan-China tensions.
They noted that President Lee Teng-hui's controversial 1995 U.S. visit infuriated Beijing, which responded by freezing what had been slowly warming semi-official contacts with Taipei.
"The effect has yet to be seen," said Chu Hai-yuan of Academia Sinica, Taiwan's top academic institution.

Chu recalled that China retaliated for the U.S. trip a month after what Taiwan had billed as Lee's "victorious return" and ratcheted up the pressure with round after round of war games and missile tests that ended only after Taiwan's election in March 1996.
"Who would have thought the mainland would react that strongly?" Chu said.
National Taiwan University law professor Shih Tzu-yi said Chang's European appearance was unlikely to bring change.
"Try as he might, Chang cannot change our diplomatic condition," Shih said.
National Chengchi University diplomacy professor Lee Teng-ke said Chang's speech at most "would increase EU understanding of Taiwan" -- but could not be seen as a breakthrough.
